question: How many tasks can you think of that you've been putting off this week, even though you kept thinking "I need to do this"?
explanation: That procrastination might not be "weak willpower" - it could be perfectionism hitting the brakes.

limitations: Hard to apply in situations that genuinely demand high quality
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the link between procrastination and perfectionism through observational research

question: What's the first thing you can do to lower "initiation resistance"?
choices: Open your laptop and just open one file
explanation: The physical act of "opening a file" can be the trigger that switches your brain into "work mode." You don't need to wait for motivation.
actionable_advice: ðŸ’¡ Right now: Sit down at your PC and just open one document (you don't have to write anything)

best_for: People who struggle to get started
limitations: Sometimes you open the file and still stop there
expanded_details.citation_role: Theoretically explains the connection between implementation intentions and physical actions

question: When you're stuck thinking "I need to do this" but can't move, what's the smallest action you can do in 10 seconds?
choices: Open your laptop lid and press the power button
Write out your entire task list
explanation: Physical actions like "opening the lid" and "pressing the power button" tend to make it easier to switch into task mode. Move your body before you think. Just once. ("Writing out the full list" and "waiting for motivation" take too long.)
actionable_advice: ðŸ‘‰ When you're stuck: Open your laptop lid and press the power button (that's the first step)

best_for: People who struggle to get started
limitations: If your PC is already open, you'll need a different minimum action
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the effect of minimum actions from procrastination research
expanded_details.try_this: ðŸ‘‰ When you're stuck: Open your laptop and press the power button (10 seconds)

tiny_metric.before_prompt: How much do you "not want to do it" right now? (0-10)
tiny_metric.success_rule: Any decrease at all is OK
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If no change, retreat for today

fallback.next: Just open a work app on your phone

question: When you decide to do "just one step," you sometimes find yourself moving on to the next step without realizing it.
explanation: The brain uses energy to "start." Once you've started, the barrier to continue tends to be lower.

limitations: Sometimes you stop after one step (and that's still OK)
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the initiation effect from implementation intention research

question: When you can't start a task, which of these fits you best?
choices: I don't know where to begin
I freeze trying to do it perfectly
It's too much hassle to move
explanation: All answers are valid. Noticing your pattern makes it easier to choose the right strategy.

question: Why is it effective to narrow "today's tasks" down to just one?
choices: It reduces choice overload, making it easier to get started
Committing to just one lets you slack off
explanation: The burden of deciding "what to start with" is a major component of initiation resistance. Spending 10 seconds in the morning to decide "just this today" tends to make it easier to move. Just once. ("Getting tired from multiple tasks" and "slacking off" miss the point - reducing decision fatigue is key.)
actionable_advice: ðŸ‘‰ When you wake up: Grab your phone and write "today's 1 task" in a notes app in 10 seconds

best_for: People who can't move because they have too many tasks
limitations: Hard to apply when multiple tasks are genuinely urgent
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the focusing effect in implementation intentions
expanded_details.try_this: ðŸ‘‰ When you wake up: Write "today's 1 task" in a notes app in 10 seconds

tiny_metric.before_prompt: How many days this week did you write "1 task"?
tiny_metric.after_prompt: On those days, were you able to get started?
tiny_metric.success_rule: Even 2 days a week is OK
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't write it for a whole week, stop

comparator.baseline: Looking at your to-do list and feeling overwhelmed

question: Not finishing a task can be less stressful than "not having started it at all."
explanation: When "things you haven't done" keep lingering in your mind, it tends to cause stress (Zeigarnik effect). Even taking one step to start can reduce this mental burden.

best_for: People who feel stressed about "things they haven't done"
limitations: Some people can't stop once they start - they may need a different approach
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the psychological burden of incomplete tasks through observational research

question: When you "don't feel motivated," what's the first physical thing you can do?
choices: Sit in your chair and place your hands on the desk
Watch motivational videos on social media
explanation: Physical actions like "sitting in the chair" and "placing your hands on the desk" can sometimes trigger your brain to switch into work mode. Move your body before you think. Just once. ("Lying down" and "watching social media" tend to make it harder to move.)
actionable_advice: ðŸ‘‰ When you don't feel motivated: Just sit in your chair and place your hands on the desk (10 seconds only)

best_for: People who spend a long time waiting for motivation
limitations: If there's no chair available, you'll need a different action
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the connection between physical movement and task initiation
expanded_details.try_this: ðŸ‘‰ When you don't feel motivated: Sit in your chair and place your hands on the desk (10 seconds)

tiny_metric.success_rule: Any increase at all is OK
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If no change, try a different method

fallback.next: Switch to just opening your PC

question: Of the techniques you learned today, which one could you use starting tomorrow?
choices: "Open laptop lid and press power" minimum action
"Sit in chair and place hands on desk" physical action
explanation: All of them are worth trying. If one doesn't fit, try another. That's learning too. Just once. ("All of them" is fine too, but no need to push yourself - start with just one.)
actionable_advice: ðŸ‘‰ Tomorrow morning, write "today's 1 task" in a notes app in 10 seconds (writing it is the first step)

best_for: People who want to try new habits
